Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on misleading photos and does not provide sufficient evidence to prove the spread of Kawasaki disease in babies during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the photos shared on Facebook are evidence of Kawasaki disease spreading in babies, without considering alternative explanations or verifying the accuracy of the images.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that one of the photos shows a skin blister caused by Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD), not Kawasaki disease.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that HFMD and Kawasaki disease are two distinct diseases, as confirmed by a member of the Philippine Society of Public Health Physicians.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity and uncertainty surrounding the relationship between COVID-19 and Kawasaki-like syndrome, as mentioned by the World Health Organization and The Lancet report.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting misleading information and not providing a comprehensive understanding of the topic.
